metadata.rationale: Extracted from canonical script and scene co-occurrence data.

data.description: Dante De La Cruz is a mid-to-late 20s woman of mixed Haitian and Puerto Rican heritage with milk chocolate skin, dark hair, and big brown eyes. She is a newly hired broker-in-training at BEL Inc. in 1997 Manhattan, driven by a traumatic childhood marked by domestic violence and poverty. Fiercely ambitious, street-smart, and emotionally guarded, she is determined to achieve wealth and power so that no one can ever harm or control her again. She is simultaneously raw and resilient, navigating a brutal, chauvinistic financial world while concealing her vulnerabilities behind wit, bravado, and calculated self-control.
data.dialogue_summary: Dante's dialogue moves between three registers: guarded ambition (her interview answers about wanting power and wealth), social navigation (attempting to charm or deflect the brokers, warming to Greta and Liliane), and raw vulnerability (her drunken confession to Abe about her family and past). She is often reactive rather than expository, revealing character through action and brief, pointed lines rather than monologue. Her most defining spoken moments are her interview declaration of wanting to be 'somebody nobody can fuck with,' her heel-throwing quip to the trading floor, and her whispered threat to Joaquin in the men's bathroom. Her phone call in the washroom early in the day reveals an unguarded, joyful side she otherwise suppresses. Her drunken cab ride home exposes exhaustion, self-doubt, and dark humor about her origins.

explicit_evidence.quote: Because I want to be rich. I want to be powerful. Because I want to be somebody that nobody can fuck with.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. OFFICE, WINTER, 1997 - JUST BEFORE DAWN

explicit_evidence.quote: And... you should know that I may not know how to use these for walking ... but, I certainly know how to use them as a weapon.
explicit_evidence.trait: Resourcefulness and quick thinking under pressure

explicit_evidence.quote: Knowing she has a narrow window before full absorption, she kneels by the toilet and forces herself to vomit.
Do you want to keep both of these, or shall I bring one to Abe, as bounty, and create my own destiny?
explicit_evidence.trait: Courage and defiance in the face of intimidation

explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. DINGY MOTEL ROOM - LATE DAY

explicit_evidence.quote: Whatever she's thinking about, it's bigger than this moment. Her jaw sets with quiet determination. Two years. She only needs two years.
Shit. I hate talking about my family. I never talk about this stuff.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER
explicit_evidence.trait: Emotional vulnerability and difficulty discussing family

explicit_evidence.quote: I have never worn heels in my entire life.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. GEMINI'S BAR VIP ROOM - LATER

explicit_evidence.quote: No, thank you Liliane. You can burn those.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: EXT. SAK'S FIFTH AVE FRONT ENTRANCE - CONTINUOUS
explicit_evidence.trait: Willingness to discard her past identity

explicit_evidence.quote: Thank you, Greta. You are so kind.
explicit_evidence.source_scene: INT. BEL INC. CORRIDOR - RIGHT OF THE PIT
explicit_evidence.trait: Gratitude and warmth toward genuine kindness

inferred_traits.rationale: As a child witnessing her mother being beaten, Young Dante counts in Spanish. The same counting is heard as an adult V.O. in the opening interview scene, suggesting this is an ingrained anxiety response.
inferred_traits.value: Counts in Spanish when overwhelmed or frightened, a habit rooted in childhood trauma

inferred_traits.rationale: Dante correctly identifies Dunaway as the man with testicular cancer (one testicle) by listening carefully to Xander's offhand comment, fulfilling Abe's challenge without appearing to try.
inferred_traits.value: Highly observant and capable of using information tactically even while intoxicated

inferred_traits.rationale: She is overwhelmed by Saks Fifth Avenue, has never worn heels, carries a cheap purse that Cassandra eyes with disgust, and wears fake perfume. She burns her old clothes rather than keep them, signaling a desire to erase her past.
inferred_traits.value: Acutely aware of her lower-class origins and eager to shed them, but occasionally betrayed by inexperience

inferred_traits.rationale: She attempts girl-code with Laynah (lipstick on teeth), tries to warm up to the brokers with humor, and recognizes Greta as a genuine ally immediately.
inferred_traits.value: Reads social dynamics quickly and attempts to build alliances even in hostile environments

inferred_traits.rationale: She drinks heavily to fit in but then deliberately purges and rehydrates in the bathroom, demonstrating that her risk-taking is calculated rather than impulsive.
inferred_traits.value: Willing to take extreme risks but applies self-regulation when survival is at stake

inferred_traits.rationale: She defers to Abe verbally ('Yes, sir') but internally resists, and physically retaliates against Joaquin's sexual coercion rather than submitting.
inferred_traits.trait: Distrust of authority figures, especially men
inferred_traits.value: Defaults to compliance with powerful men but maintains internal resistance and self-protective instincts

inferred_traits.rationale: The high heel throwing star moment and her quip 'No shirt, no shoes, no service?' to Abe demonstrate her use of humor to neutralize threatening situations.
inferred_traits.value: Uses wit and self-deprecating humor to deflect hostility and gain social footing

data.name: DANTE

relationships.evidence: Cassandra vouches for Dante's hiring, takes her to Saks, funds her wardrobe, and explicitly tells her to 'do exactly what I say. Always.' Dante is simultaneously grateful and wary.
Abe tests Dante with the 'one nut' challenge, alternates between cruelty and warmth, and ultimately holds her employment fate. Dante defers to him while trying to read and impress him.
Joaquin sexually coerces Dante in the men's bathroom, threatening her job. Dante physically retaliates by grabbing his testicles and threatening him.
Greta immediately nurtures Dante, gives her Tylenol and band-aids, defends her implicitly, and offers unconditional support. Dante responds with genuine warmth.
Laynah shoots Dante a murderous glare on day one, refers to her as 'Dominican street trash,' and plants a soiled colleague at Dante's desk as a 'welcome present.'
Xander gives Dante water to balance her drinking, inadvertently provides the key clue about Dunaway's testicular cancer, and tells her to leave when Joaquin threatens her.
The opening scene of Dante's mother being beaten while Dante counts in Spanish establishes the foundational wound driving all of Dante's ambition and self-protective behavior.
The father is depicted as a large, frightening figure who strikes Dante's mother and silences Young Dante with a finger to his lips before walking out.
relationships.relationship_type: Source of childhood trauma / Absent threat
